definition: Testing that validates whether a system meets business requirements and is ready for deployment or release, often defined or reviewed by business stakeholders.
The layer in the Generic Test Automation Architecture (gTAA) that connects Robot Framework to the System Under Test or automated systems via keyword libraries.
An execution element such as a library keyword or Robot Framework language statement that does not contain child steps; its status is determined only by its own execution result.
A Robot Framework suite, test, task, or keyword collection that automates a defined workflow or behavior.
A value passed to a keyword when it is called to customize its behavior. Arguments can have different kinds (for example positional, named, embedded) and may be mandatory or optional.
The complete, ordered list of arguments that a keyword accepts, including their names, kinds, default values and optional type hints, as shown in keyword documentation.
A development approach and collaboration practice that describes system behavior in business-readable language, often using Given/When/Then phrasing.

A declarative specification style in Robot Framework where tests|tasks describe system behavior from the user’s perspective, typically using natural-language-like steps with embedded arguments and prefixes such as Given/When/Then/And/But.
Special variables provided by Robot Framework that expose execution-related information such as paths, timestamps, and status without needing explicit definition.
The interface used to run Robot Framework from the command line (e.g. with the `robot` command), configure execution options, and pass arguments or variables.

An execution element that is composed of other elements (for example a suite composed of tests|tasks, a test|task composed of keywords, or a user keyword composed of child keywords and statements) and whose status is derived from its children.
Statements like `IF`, `FOR`, `WHILE`, `BREAK` and `CONTINUE` used in Robot Framework to control the execution flow inside a test, task or keyword.
A style where the same logic or test flow is executed multiple times with different input and/or expected output data, often implemented using test|task templates in Robot Framework.
The layer in the Generic Test Automation Architecture (gTAA) containing the test data, such as suites, tests, tasks, resource files, keywords, and variables written in Robot Framework syntax.

An argument written directly into a keyword name using the `${}` variable syntax; its value is mandatory and must appear in that position when the keyword is called, often used in behavior-driven style steps.
Tests that verify complete workflows across all relevant components, subsystems and interfaces to ensure that real-world user flows behave as expected.
Files and outputs generated by Robot Framework execution, such as `output.xml`, `log.html`, and `report.html`, which document what was executed and with which results.
The layer in the Generic Test Automation Architecture (gTAA) that includes Robot Framework’s parser, execution engine, logging, and reporting components which interpret test data and run keywords.
The internal representation created by Robot Framework after parsing suites, tests, tasks, and keywords, which the execution engine uses to perform automation.
An execution status indicating that an element (such as a keyword, test, task or suite) did not meet its expected outcome or raised an error during execution.
A control structure in Robot Framework used to iterate over items in a list or other iterable and execute a body of keywords for each item.
A catch-all named argument kind marked with ** that gathers all named values not explicitly defined elsewhere into a dictionary; optional and supplied using name=value pairs.
A layered reference architecture for test automation that defines separation into definition, execution, and adaptation layers; used to describe Robot Framework’s role in an automation solution.
Conventional prefixes used in behavior-driven specification style. Robot Framework can ignore these prefixes when matching keywords if the remaining part of the name matches a keyword.
A variable with global scope that can be accessed from all suites and keywords in a Robot Framework execution.
A directory that is treated as a suite because it (directly or indirectly) contains at least one suite file; it groups lower-level suites into a suite tree.
A suite file located in a directory that configures that directory as a suite and can define suite-level settings, variables, setups and teardowns for all contained suites.
A comment written either at the very beginning, or at the end of a line in a Robot Framework file, separated by at least two spaces and starting with a # so that it is ignored by the interpreter.
A compact IF statement form on a single line (`IF  <condition>  <keyword>  [args]`) used to execute one keyword conditionally without an END.
A categorization of learning objectives based on Bloom’s Taxonomy: **K1** (Remember), **K2** (Understand), and **K3** (Apply), indicating the expected depth of knowledge.
A named, reusable action or sequence of actions in Robot Framework that can be called from tests, tasks or other keywords and may accept arguments and may return values.
The documented information of a keyword, including its name, arguments (with kinds and types), return values, documentation, and examples, as exposed for example by HTML documentation or IDEs.
An imperative specification style in Robot Framework where tests|tasks are written as sequences of keyword calls with arguments, focusing on what actions are executed and in which order.

A collection of library keywords implemented typically in Python (or other languages) that Robot Framework imports to interact with external systems, perform computations or provide utility functions.
A Robot Framework variable of list type, accessed with the `@{}` syntax, that can hold an ordered collection of values and can be unpacked when passed to keywords.
A variable whose scope is limited to a single keyword, test or task execution and is not visible outside of that body.
A detailed HTML execution log generated by Robot Framework that shows keyword-level execution steps, arguments, messages and statuses.
Arguments without a default value that must be provided when calling a keyword; they appear before optional arguments and a call fails if they are missing.
Key–value information defined with the Metadata setting in a suite, used to document additional attributes such as author, version, or related requirements.

An argument that must be provided by name (never positionally); typically defined after a "Variable Number of Positional Arguments" or explicitly marked with a label icon in docs, and can be mandatory or optional.
The main machine-readable execution result file produced by Robot Framework, containing the full execution tree, messages, and statistics in XML format.

Arguments that have a default value or are optional catch-alls (such as a "Variable Number of Positional Arguments" marked with * or "Free Named Arguments" marked with **); they can be omitted, follow mandatory arguments in the interface, and default to predefined values when not provided.
An execution status indicating that an element (such as a keyword, test, task or suite) executed successfully and its expectations were met.
A keyword argument provided solely by its position in the argument list without naming it explicitly.

Arguments that appear before a Variable Number of Positional Arguments or Named-Only Arguments and can be set either by position or by name (but not both for the same value); they may be mandatory or optional.
A high-level HTML summary of a Robot Framework execution that focuses on statistics and overall pass/fail status of suites and tests|tasks.
A file (commonly with extension .resource or .robot) that contains user keywords and variables and is imported by suites to share and reuse these artifacts.
A statement used in user keywords to return one or more values that can be assigned to variables in the calling context.
A documented indication of the type of value a keyword returns, helping users understand how to use the returned data.
Automation of business processes or tasks normally performed by humans, often across multiple systems, without necessarily focusing on testing.
The non-profit association (Robot Framework ry) that stewards the development, ecosystem, governance and promotion of Robot Framework and its community.
The foundational certification level for Robot Framework that validates understanding of core concepts, syntax and basic control structures.
The top-level suite in a Robot Framework execution, determined by the initial directory or file path passed to the robot command.
The standard variable access form in Robot Framework used to read values regardless of whether the underlying variable was defined as scalar, list-like or dictionary-like.
A Robot Framework variable accessed with the `${}` syntax that holds a single value of any supported data type.
An execution status indicating that an element (such as a test or task) was intentionally not executed, for example due to selection options or an explicit skip.
A library that is shipped with Robot Framework itself, providing generic functionality such as operating system interaction, string manipulation, or process handling.
A collection of tests or tasks (and optionally local keywords and variables) defined in a .robot file or directory that is executed as a unit by Robot Framework.
A .robot file that contains at least one test case or task and is therefore treated by Robot Framework as an executable suite.
A keyword executed once before any tests|tasks in a suite are run, typically used to prepare common preconditions.
A keyword executed once after all tests|tasks in a suite have run, typically used to clean up shared resources.
A variable whose scope covers all tests|tasks and keywords within a specific suite but is not visible outside that suite.
A proactive monitoring technique that runs automated scripts (often using tools like Robot Framework) at regular intervals against live systems to detect issues before real users are affected.
An executable entity in Robot Framework similar to a test case but conceptually used for non-testing automation such as RPA workflows; defined in a *** Tasks *** section.
A keyword executed before an individual test or task starts, used to prepare preconditions specific to that test|task.
A keyword executed after an individual test or task finishes, used to clean up resources specific to that test|task.
A setting that defines a keyword used as a template for multiple tests|tasks, where each row of data calls the template keyword with different arguments.
An executable specification in Robot Framework that verifies some aspect of a system’s behavior and is defined in a `*** Test Cases ***` section.
The collection of suites, tests, tasks, resource files, keywords and variables that define what Robot Framework will execute.
A classification of testing focus (such as unit, component, integration, system, system integration, acceptance or end-to-end) describing the scope and granularity of tests.
A label assigned to tests or tasks (using the Tags setting) to categorize them and enable filtering, selection and reporting.
A maximum allowed execution time for a keyword, test or task after which Robot Framework marks the element as failed due to timeout.

A keyword defined in Robot Framework syntax (typically in suites or resource files) that is composed of calls to other keywords and statements, often used to describe higher-level or business-oriented actions.
An optional argument kind marked with a single * that collects all remaining positional values; once present, any subsequent parameters must be provided as named arguments.
A named reference to a value or collection of values in Robot Framework, used to store data and pass it between keywords, tests and tasks.
A separate file (often a Python module or other supported format) that provides variables which can be imported into suites using the Variables setting.
The visibility and lifetime of a variable (such as global, suite, test|task, or local) during a Robot Framework execution.
A control structure in Robot Framework that repeatedly executes a block of keywords as long as a given condition evaluates to true.
